awd_titl_txt: IGE: Building practical, evidence-based teaching capacity in tomorrow's doctorates
awd_abstract_narration:
Future faculty can expect that they will instruct students from many diverse populations. While access to college science education has democratized, the methods used to teach these diverse cohorts of students are not always aligned with evidence-based best practices.  This project implements and evaluates a training approach for future faculty that leverages best practices in inclusive science teaching within a multi-stage practical experience. This National Science Foundation Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) award to the University of Washington will make use of the best features of top professional development models to innovatively prepare future professors for the unique challenges of teaching college STEM courses. The undergraduate students that the participating graduate students will teach will join the workforce having more than basic memorized knowledge: they will also understand scientific practice, know how to apply scientific thinking and generate scientific questions, and be prepared to partake in a more diverse and effective scientific community. 

This project balances cutting-edge teacher development within the constraints of modern graduate work to develop dual expertise in science and teaching. Practice of active teaching skills will help trainees develop classroom tools and teaching approaches that put engaging work in the hands of their students.  Rapid feedback from expert instructors, outside consultants, test classrooms, and their own video analysis will further their development as teachers capable of effectively employing methods far beyond simple passive lecturing. While developing a syllabus around their own cutting-edge research, trainees will be guided through challenges in a teaching course centered on diversity and equity for all students. When ready, trainees will teach their own mentored courses to college seniors as a starting point for careers that include ambitious and equitable teaching of science. These courses will introduce undergraduates directly to current research in their field of study as taught by the scientists actively doing the work. Success of the training for each graduate instructor will be investigated and communicated through interviews with students, student project work, and professional evaluation by expert instructors in the field.  Collectively, these results will inform the overall evaluation of the training approach.        

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcomes for IGE #1855841:

Building practical, evidence-based teaching capacity in tomorrow's doctorates

 

College STEM professors instruct many thousands of students, but their training in active and inclusive teaching is often marginal or gained only in the midst of complex research and teaching careers. It is in this learning context that talented STEM students must navigate their foundational coursework, and this contributes to inequities that we see in STEM success and lack of skill building for STEM careers. To maximize the success of future generations of scientists, our students in STEM need professors who teach with great equity, great skill-development, and without the need to learn their teaching craft through teaching many courses. Grant #1855841 provided the support to develop, run, and research the training of excellent college science instructors within the constraints of their science PhDs.

 

The Science Teaching Experience Program for Upcoming PhDs (STEP-UP) was based at the University of Washington. Advanced graduate students in a broad range of STEM fields were taught through a multi-step program in which they learned the fundamentals of education philosophy, practiced large-scale and micro-skills in teaching with expert guidance, and developed courses within their areas of active research. Under the mentorship of experienced professional developers, the trainees in STEP-UP taught new courses to STEM students.

 

Independent research on the teaching of these trainees and the experiences of their students found the teaching and learning in these courses to be excellent. Students were driven to engage in high-level scientific skill development and perceived these STEM courses to be demanding, emotionally supportive, and more inclusive than other courses taught by much more experienced instructors. The direct observation of STEP-UP-trained instructors compared favorably in their depth of active learning techniques when measured against a national sample of experienced professors. These benefits were achieved without slowing the progress of their PhD graduations, and alumni found the experience to be central to their career progress and earning new faculty positions. These findings were published in two peer-reviewed manuscripts.

 

Throughout STEP-UP, thirty-one graduating STEM PhDs developed critical teaching skills and direct experience that show them to be successful STEM instructors already. This program, and others that might draw on design elements identified by this funded research, have the potential to overhaul instructional techniques and STEM equity throughout academia. In particular, STEP-UP focused on practice-based skill development and authentic practice opportunities for those skills. These aspects, which are described in research manuscripts now, will stand as a model for institutions to successfully and efficiently broaden the skills of their graduate scientist instructors.
